key_mistakes.reason: Blocks the natural development of pieces and doesn't fight for the center.
Blocks the knight's natural development square and weakens the center.
Develops the bishop to a passive square and leaves the center unprotected.
Allows the opponent to capture the bishop and weakens the pawn structure.
Exposes the king and loses material advantage.
Allows the opponent to simplify the position with a queen exchange.
Weakens the king's position and doesn't improve the piece coordination.
Weakens the pawn structure and doesn't create significant threats.

recommendations: Focus on controlling the center with pawns and pieces.
Develop pieces to their most active squares.
Avoid unnecessary pawn moves that can weaken your position.
Ensure king safety before launching an attack.
